issue.title: Access to the LazyWrapper
issue.body: One of the joys of using Lo-Dash is it's [extensibility](http://eng.rightscale.com/2015/01/22/lodash-extensions.html). With Lo-Dash 3, is it possible to extend the Lazy evaluation mechanism? If not, can that be considered as a feature request?

issue.title: _.ary can create wrappers with exact arity.
issue.body:
This pull request allows `_.ary` to take an extra argument, which when true, creates a wrapper function that has the exact right arity.

```js
_.ary(fn, 5).length === 5
```

There's are a couple of JS libraries where function arity is important (Express, for instance).

issue.title: RegExp escape discussion

comment.body:
EscapeRegExpPattern (what `.source` uses internally) takes a pattern and escapes it so that it can be represented as a string.

What `RegExp.escape` does is take a string and escapes it so it can be literally represented as a pattern.

While the two are related operations - they don't need to have the same escape set.

However, we're still debating whether or not `/` and other similar characters need to be escaped so I'll update you as soon as either me or allen change our mind :)

commits.message: Ensure `_.escapeRegExp` handles empty strings in a way to work with compilation.

issue.title: Support native ES6 Iterable protocol [Symbol.iterator]
issue.body:
This would be a pretty nice stepping stone into ES6 compatibility. Reverse of #737.

I'm not too familiar with the code but here's my high level take:
* Define only if `Symbol.iterator` is defined
* `lodash.prototype[Symbol.iterator]` returns a stateful object with i=0
* `next()` will return `{ value: at(i++), done: false }` or `{ value: null, done: true }`

I'm willing to implement this if you feel like this would be a useful addition.

comment.body: Hi @fengb! I'm not considering it at the moment but feel free to experiment with this.

issue.title: RegExp escape discussion

comment.body:
Yep. I remember now why I added escaping `/` because I saw it escaped in `RegExp#source` for example:
```js
RegExp('/').source // => "\/"
```

issue.title: _.ary can create wrappers with exact arity.
issue.body:
This pull request allows `_.ary` to take an extra argument, which when true, creates a wrapper function that has the exact right arity.

```js

```

There's are a couple of JS libraries where function arity is important (Express, for instance).

comment.body:
> How about exposing the metaMap so people can mix this in

I don't want to expose `metaMap`. It's a nice thing that can melt away if needed.

issue.title: _.ary can create wrappers with exact arity.
issue.body:
This pull request allows `_.ary` to take an extra argument, which when true, creates a wrapper function that has the exact right arity.

```js
_.ary(fn, 5).length === 5
```

There's are a couple of JS libraries where function arity is important (Express, for instance).

comment.body:
How about exposing the metaMap so people can mix this in @jdd?

On Fri, Jun 19, 2015 at 9:38 PM, John-David Dalton <notifications@github.com
> wrote:

> After some time to think, we've made it this long in node land without
> this I don' think we need to start attempting this support now. Relying on
> .length of functions will only get trickier with ES6 because it's
> configurable and because things like default params affect them.
>
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/lodash/lodash/pull/1251#issuecomment-113694783>.
>

issue.title: _.branch: _.pick and _.omit simultaneously
_.branch: _.pick and _.omit simultaneously

comment.body: Thanks for the suggestion @dlindenkreuz! I'll keep an eye on the demand for this. Until then you can create a mixin to kick the tires a bit.

issue.title: _.ary can create wrappers with exact arity.
issue.body:
This pull request allows `_.ary` to take an extra argument, which when true, creates a wrapper function that has the exact right arity.

```js
_.ary(fn, 5).length === 5
```

There's are a couple of JS libraries where function arity is important (Express, for instance).

comment.body: After some time to think, we've made it this long in node land without this I don' think we need to start attempting this support now. Relying on `.length` of functions will only get trickier with ES6 because it's configurable and because things like default params affect them.

issue.title: _.branch: _.pick and _.omit simultaneously

comment.body: Exactly. Didn't even think of `partition` for arrays in the first place, but yes, that's totally what I'm talking about.

issue.title: _.branch: _.pick and _.omit simultaneously

comment.body: So you're requesting some sort of `partitionObject`?

comment.body: Its probably worth caching these strings, I imagine they are expensive to create
